computer.description:
The Model 16 was the same as a Model 12 with the 68000 add-on. It was launched a few time after the Tandy TRS 80 model IV. The Z80 processor was used for I/O. Up to four hard disks could be connected (8.4 mb each). It was compatible with the Tandy TRS 80 model II thanks to the Z80 and could run the Model II operating system.
This 68000 chip set and associated memory were much more than a speed improvement. It created a multi-user Unix-based system (actually Xenix, which was just a scaled down Unix). Interestingly, Xenix was developed in part by Microsoft, it was probably the basis upon which some Unix-like functionalities were added to MS-DOS 2.0, like sub-directories, pipes and re-direction.
The 16/6000 had a maximum memory capacity of 768K, and up to 9 serial ports for external terminals. These limits were partly just physical, due to limited card slot space. The 3-port serial cards had jumpers that would have allowed quite a few of them given an external card cage (never produced).
The 768K memory limit was later bumped to 1 MB when 64K memory chips became available. The original machine used a memory card of 256KB populated with 16K chips, and cables were available to support up to three cards. With 64K chips only one card was needed to give 1 MB of memory. Operating system limitations prevented using multiple 1 M cards to expand further in user memory space, but it was possible with software to utilize up to an additional 7 MB of memory as the system "swapper" which, given only 1 MB of user space, was almost always a source of performance loss if handled by the hard drive.
Thanks to Mark Brumlik for the main part of information.

emulator.description: This program emulates a complete TRS-80
emulator.name: David Keil's TRS-80 Model III/4/4P Emulator Page

emulator.description: This page offers shareware versions of a TRS-80 Model 4 emulator and a TRS-80 Model 1-2 emulator

emulator.description: This TRS-80 Model III/4 Emulator is a commercial product
emulator.name: TRS-80 Model III/4 Emulator

emulator.description: xtrs is a Radio Shack TRS-80 Model I/III/4/4P emulator for Unix and the X Window System
emulator.name: xtrs: TRS-80 Model I/III/4 Emulator for Unix

emulator.description: With this Java emulator, you'll be able to write a BASIC program directly in your browser!
emulator.name: TRS-80 Level I BASIC in a browser

emulator.description: A complete list of TRS-80 emulators for various platforms !
emulator.name: Ira Goldklang's TRS-80 Revived Pages

emulator.description: MESS emulator also emulates a TRS-80 systems
emulator.name: MESS

item.description: Remote Unit Active|||Serial# 26-1210|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> REMOTE UNIT ACTIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1210</strong><br><blockquote>This rare unit is meant for teachers to control up to 16 TRS-80 Model 1 from a another TRS-80 equiped with min-disk. All the controled TRS-80 model 1 must be equiped with Level II. <br><br> It cost 2895fr (France, 1981)</blockquote>

Network II box|||p/n 26-1211|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> NETWORK II BOX</strong></font><br><strong>> p/n 26-1211</strong><br><blockquote>This box allowed up to 16 TRS computer to be networked. Three network boxes were released by Tandy (I, II and III).<br> The Network II required verbal communication between the server operator and the remote user, and data transfer had to be completed one user at a time.<br> The network III allowed automated control of the network so that users could easily access programs and data stored on the server's storage device.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>David Sutherland</b> for the pictures.</p></blockquote>

Daisy Wheel Printer II|||Serial# 26-1158|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAISY WHEEL PRINTER II</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1158</strong><br><blockquote>This is a high-quality printer meant to be used with wordprocessors. Some interchangeable daisy-wheels were available (Courrier, Elite, Madeleine). It could print 163 characters per line (34cm), at a 43 cps rate. <br><br> It cost 9595fr (France, 1981)</blockquote>

Line Printer I |||Ref# 26-7017|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> LINE PRINTER I </strong></font><br><strong>> Ref# 26-7017</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a custom version of the Oki Microline 80.<br> Printed lower and upper case on paper rolls or listing paper (24cm wide) from 40 to 80 columns/line, at a speed rate of 28 lines/minute. <br><br> It cost 716 Euros in 1981 (France).</blockquote>

Line Printer III|||Serial# 26-1156|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> LINE PRINTER III</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1156</strong><br><blockquote>This printer can print lower and upper case, at a speed rate of 120 c/s, on paper up to 38cm wide. It is conceived for intensive use ! <br<<br> It cost 9950fr in 1981 (France). </blockquote>

Line Printer VI|||Serial# 26-1166|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> LINE PRINTER VI</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1166</strong><br><blockquote>This large printer can print lower and upper case, graphic characters and symbols at a speed rate of 100 c/s ! This is definately a professional printer. <br><br> It cost 5495fr in 1981 (France).</blockquote>

Exatron |||Stringy Floppy drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> EXATRON </strong></font><br><strong>> Stringy Floppy drive</strong><br><blockquote>The Exatron Stringy Floppy (ESF) was a low-cost data—storage system that fitted the gap, between cassettes and disk drives.<br> The system was based on a miniature endless—loop tape cartridge called a "wafer".<br> The amount of data that could be recorded on a wafer depended on the length of tape in it, typically, a 50—foot wafer could hold at least 40 KB of programs or data. <br><br> <b>Matt</b> reports to us:<br><font color="#666666"> A curiousity about the model 1, CPU SPEED had a direct relatonship with STORAGE CAPACITY. if you doubled the clock speed of your MODEL 1 CPU you doubled the amount of data you could store on your stringy floppies. this is a feat that no other computer no matter how many ghz you have in your PC can do today without using compression.</font> <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>David Sutherland</b> for the pictures</p></blockquote>

computer.media: One or Two 8'' floppy disk drives
computer.name: TRS 80 MODEL 16
